coredata.dc:title: Spectroscopic and chemical characterisation of “fullerene black”
coredata.dc:creator: Werner, H.
Herein, D.
Blöcker, J.
Henschke, B.
Tegtmeyer, U.
Schedel-Niedrig, Th.
Keil, M.
Bradshaw, A.M.
Schlögl, R.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
The electric arc method of fullerene preparation leaves about 90% of the carbon as insoluble soot. Unprotected storage of C60 also leads to insoluble carbonaceous material. This “fullerene black” has been characterised with respect to its structural, electron spectroscopic and chemical properties. Comparison of the results with data obtained from industrial carbon black shows that the insoluble residue has nothing in common with conventional soot which is composed of small graphitic structural units. Fullerene black as well as pure C60 and C70 were all found to exhibit high reactivities in combustion reactions under realistic conditions.

xocs:doc.xocs:rawtext: Volume 194, number 1,2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 19 June 1992 Spectroscopic and chemical characterisation of "fullerene black" H. Werner a, D. Herein a, j. Bli~cker a, B. Henschke a, U. Tegtmeyer ~, Th. Schedel-Niedrig b, M. Keil b, A.M. Bradshaw b and R. Schl~gl a,b a InstitutJ~r Anorganische Chemie der Universitiit, Niederurseler Hang, W-6000 Frankfurt 50, Germany b Fritz-Haber-lnstitut der Max-Planck-Gesellschaft, Faradayweg 4, W-IO00 Berlin 33, Germany Received 2 December 1991; in final form 14 April 1992 The electric arc method of fullerene preparation leaves about 90% of the carbon as insoluble soot. Unprotected storage of C6o also leads to insoluble carbonaceous material. This "fullerene black" has been characterised with respect to its structural, electron spectroscopic and chemical properties. Comparison of the results with data obtained from industrial carbon black shows that the insoluble residue has nothing in common with conventional soot which is composed of small graphitic structural units. Fullerene black as well as pure C6o and C7o were all found to exhibit high reactivities in combustion reactions under realistic conditions. The conventional preparation of fullerenes [ 1 ] via a carbon plasma leaves about 90% of the material as insoluble "soot". It has therefore been proposed [2 ] that fullerenes perhaps form the nuclei of conven- tional soot [ 3 ] which should there resemble in its structural and electronic properties the material ob- tained as waste in the fullerene synthesis. In this Let- ter we present experiments to check the similarity of these two carbon materials both of which lack long range order. The chemical reactivity of conventional soot, fullerene soot and pure C6o/C7o with respect to oxidation are compared. The large differences pro- vide clear evidence for the different nature of the carbon particles. This investigation also provides further insight into a practically relevant property of the new form of carbon. For the use of fullerenes as advanced materials [ 4 ] easy handling is a necessary pre-requisite, in partic- ular, the number of practical applications will in- crease if the material is thermally stable in air. From the synthesis it might be expected that some of the energy of the carbon plasma remains as internal en- ergy in the fullerene soot material and might be re- leased in a chemical reaction such as the oxidation. Correspondence to: R. Schl6gl, Institut fiir Anorganische Chemic der Universit~it, Niederurscler Hang, W-6000 Frankfurt 50, Germany. We have prepared the energy-rich carbon material in a conventional dc arc apparatus and extracted the toluene-soluble fraction from which we separated pure C6o by column chromatography. Sample purity was checked by IR [2], ~3C NMR and UV-VIS spectroscopies [ 4 ]. The residual fullerene black was studied by X-ray diffraction (Bragg-Brentano ge- ometry, Co Ka radiation). In fig. 1 the resulting dif- fraction pattern is compared to that of an industrial carbon black (FW 1 from DEGUSSA, Hanau). The sharp reflection is the (002) peak of graphite from the starting electrode (identical Ic values of 340 pm are indicative of defective graphite). The peak at 20= 8 is absent in carbon black and the maxima of the inelastic scattering features are clearly different. Both carbons are nanocrystalline materials with dif- ferent basic structural building blocks. The inset shows SEM photographs of uncoated samples of ful- lerene black and carbon black revealing the hetero- geneous nature of the fullerene black with large par- ticles embedded in a dust of ~50-100 nm particulates. Under the same imaging conditions carbon black exhibits a very strong tendency to agglomerate. The electronic structure of fullerene black was studied by X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) on the SX 700-IV monochromator at BESSY. Total yield spectra of carbon black, from a C6o film on Cu ( 100 ) 62 0009-2614/92/$ 05.00 1992 Elsevier Science Publishers B.V. All rights reserved. Powder X-ray diffraction patterns (Co Ka radiation) of carbon black and fullerene black. The SEM images show the morphology of loose powder samples (25 keV, SEI, no coating). 4.0 XANES I r I 3.5 3.0 2.5 "E :) 2.0 1.5 /f'~, / I \.. / I' J ., / / i, -J "-/ /',,; 0.5 *- 0.0 , I , , I 280 290 300 310 / -~ ..................... 320 Energy E eV ] Fig. 2. X-ray absorption spectra of carbon black FW-I ( ..... ), C~o (- - -) as a thin film on Cu and fullerene black ( ). and from fullerene black are compared in fig. 2. The data are free of angular orientation effects as ex- pected from powder samples. The high resolution spectrum of C6o agrees well with observations in the literature [ 5 ]. It differs significantly from that of carbon black due to the molecular versus extended 63 Volume 194, number 1,2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 19 June 1992 character of the electronic structures. The distribu- tion of 7r* and o'* states is different in the graphitic material and in C6o [ 5,6 ]. The shifts of the onsets of the lowest n* transitions are due to a shift in the ini- tial state C ls positions (284.5 eV for FW1,284.9 eV for C6o and 285.2 eV for fullerene black). The overall shape of the fullerene black spectrum resem- bles much more that of C6o than that of carbon black. Taking into account the differences in the XAS data of C6o and C7o [ 5 ] and comparing the present data to medium resolution spectra in the literature [ 7 ], the electronic structure of the fullerene black points to icosaspiral building blocks of this material rather than to the presence of graphitic elements. The fundamental difference between fuUerene black and carbon black was further substantiated in oxidation experiments. In fig. 3 the onset curves for oxygen uptake by several carbon materials are shown. The reaction conditions at ambient pressure were 5 at% oxygen in nitrogen passing with a space velocity of 8 X 104 h- i over 200 mg material heated at 8 K min- 1. The molecular solids are of comparable sta- bility to the reference carbon black. The sample FW- 1 was the most reactive industrial carbon black out of a variety of carbons investigated [ 8 ]. The lower stability of C7o was already reported in a gravimetric experiment [9 ] with the onset temperatures for re- action being in good agreement with the present data. The complex reaction behaviour observed in ref. [ 9 ] (a rapid first step followed by a slower main pro- cess) is indeed well explained by the presence of a mixture of C6o and C7o exhibiting in their pure states different onset temperatures. The different rcactivities of C6o and C7o against oxygen may be used to purify C6o under defined ox- idative conditions yielding e.g. a pure C6o fraction from the conventional C6o, 10% C7o starting material. The fullerene black is much more reactive than both the two molecular solids and the reference car- bon, exhibiting a pronounced peak at very low tem- perature which is not observed with carbon black. The continuous increase in the oxygen uptake rate is due to oxygen complex formation on the large BET surface 0f267 m2 g-~ [8]. The low surface area ful- lercne black (21 m2 g-l) seems to contain a much larger number of highly active reaction sites than the carbon black. In this material the number of reaction sites is limited by the chemical anisotropy of the planar sp2 carbon rings as only prismatic faces of the layer stacks can react with oxygen [ 8 ]. The product distributions as a function of time (temperature) indicate clearly the differences in the combustion mechanisms of the various carbons. Fig. 4a shows the CO2 generation during combustion of fullercnc black. Three phases can clearly be distin- guished. The first peak from the oxygen uptake curve occurs as a sharp spike at ~ 500 K with a lineshape typical of a site-limited reaction. FW I; ( ..... ) C6o; (---) C7o. 64 Volume 194, number 1,2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 19 June 1992 4 i i i i i t ! o i ,oo b t 80 C6o 40 20 0 , I , I , l * I h I , ' 100 ' i ' i " ' ' i " ' ao~ C 80 4O 2O - F , I , i , i , 9~0- K , 0 1ool ' i ' i , i ' i ' i , i i ' I oo ~- Carbon black FW I d - I 40 2O 0 Fig. 4. Reaction profiles of combustion: (a) CO2 production dur- ing combustion of fullerene black (mass spectrometer signal for m/e 44). (b) Ratio of CO/CO2 during combustion of pure C~o; the temperatures in all diagrams indicate the reaction onsets taken from fig. 3. (c,d) Ratios of CO/CO2 during combustion of ful- lerene black and carbon black. The ordinates indicate the relative abundance of CO~, the x-~is is a time scale related via the heat- ing rate of 8 K rain- ' to the reaction temperature. unsaturated terminal C-C bonds of incomplete ico- saspirals are likely candidates for such highly reac- tive sites. Included solvent molecules are not re- sponsible for this peak as it also occurs with annealed C6o. The second process is characterised by a steady reaction differing from the case of carbon black which shows higher CO production. This can be seen from a comparison of figs. 4c and 4d showing the evolu- tion of the CO/CO2 ratio as function of reaction progress. The characteristic two-step process of a gas- solid reaction involving activation and diffusion- limited steady state conversion seen in the profile of carbon black [8] is not recognised with fullerene black. The pure molecular solid C6o gasifies uni- formly as can be seen from the flat product distil- bution ratio shown in fig. 4b. The third process in fig. 4a is a high-temperature gasification leading to a large excess of CO2 and is assigned to the com- bustion of graphitic residues from the starting electrode. The reaction patterns of C6o and fullerene black were well reproduced with different batches of each material and do not drastically change upon increas- ing the oxygen partial pressure. In pure oxygen the initial burst in fullerene black combustion is much smaller and evolution of CO2 is already observed at 300 K, as can be seen from the reaction plot in fig. 5. In this experiment 50 rag of fullerene black was exposed to an oxygen stream at a space velocity of l x l05 h-1 and subjected to the temperature treat- ment shown. The products were predominantly CO2; only a small amount of CO was detected with a sen- sitive IMR-MS mass spectrometer #1. High reactivity towards oxygen has also been reported in photoem- ission experiments which showed that exposure of only a few langmuirs of oxygen to C~o at low tem- peratures leads to entrapped CO2 and carbon bonds which remain after heating the sample to 300 K [ 11 ]. The present C6o samples were found to contain small amounts of carbon dioxide which was released upon heating in a He stream in a slow process be- ginning at 450 K. The emission was less than 0.1% of the combustion effect. CO2 was also detected in IR spectra giving rise to a peak at 2326 cm-1 a fre- quency which is slightly reduced compared to gas- eous CO2 with 2349 cm-1. The IMR-MS technique was further used to search for the presence of hereto elements such as H (H20), N (NO2), O (02). No evidence for any substantial presence of the hereto elements was found. We de- tected, however, the evolution of solvent molecules at temperatures above 500 K. Structural, spectroscopic and chemical arguments thus substantiate our proposal concerning the prin- cipal difference between fullerene black and carbon black. The basic structural units of fullerene black are not stacks of flat graphene segments but are mere likely to be fragments of icosaspirals with the ter- #1 IMR-MS is a mild ionisation technique for small molecules which are reacted with a primary jet of low-energy noble gas (Kr) ions in a special octupole collision chamber [ 10 ]. Very high sen- sitivities for CO and CO2 are advantageous in the present application. 65 Volume 194, number 1,2 CHEMICAL PHYSICS LETTERS 19 June 1992 CombusLion of fullerene residue oxygen a ~mosphere 35000 -- I I ' I i 800 C02 d -- - co ~. s~ 700 28000 ~ te~p 600 LD o 21000 500 D_ ~ 400 <D~ ro 14000 300 ~) O_ E 200 7000 ~' IO0 0 ........ t .... ,----" I _ I --'-, ..... k .... r .... t-- , 0 0 5 i0 15 20 25 30 time [min.] Fig. 5. Reaction profile (IMR-MS) of combustion of fullerene black in pure oxygen. The dotted line is the sample temperature, the full line describes the CO2 evolution, the dashed line indicates in an expanded scale the CO evolution ( X 5 ). minating atoms highly reactive towards oxidation. These fragments may well bind (like a co-polymer) intact fuUerenes which oxidise only after all the open fragments are gasified. The shape of the antibonding density f-state distribution indicates that fullerene black still contains a significant fraction of insoluble C6o as it is polymerised into the fragment matrix. The model points to interesting properties of fullerene black, quite different from "soot", and yet to be ex- plored. Further, this picture allows us to understand the transformation of the once soluble crystallised C6o after storage in air and light. Under these con- ditions some molecules are broken down [12] and form the reactive "monomers" which bind the sur- rounding, still intact C6o molecules into a fullerene black particularly rich in C6o. The stability of fuller- enes in oxidising environments was found to be highest for the most symmetric species, namely, C6o. Comparison with the oxidative stability of carbon black reveals that only C6o has a theoretical [ 13 ] chance to be involved in the creation of crystallisa- tion nucleii of soot [ 12 ]. Useful discussions with W. Kr~itschmer and the fullerene group at Hoechst AG, Frankfurt are grate- fully acknowledged. ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: The electric arc method of fullerene preparation leaves about 90% of the carbon as insoluble soot. Unprotected storage of C60 also leads to insoluble carbonaceous material. This “fullerene black” has been characterised with respect to its structural, electron spectroscopic and chemical properties. Comparison of the results with data obtained from industrial carbon black shows that the insoluble residue has nothing in common with conventional soot which is composed of small graphitic structural units. Fullerene black as well as pure C60 and C70 were all found to exhibit high reactivities in combustion reactions under realistic conditions.
